Yes! I currently have to set my interval very low (like 1 minute) and add a sleep command to my batch processing of a 1minute to allow the cache to expire to continue my batch function.  Since I know my data, I could then increase this to 24 hours or NEVER expire the cache and issue a SIGHUP when I know the data has changed.  Pretty Please! :)
any update on this? It would be really helpful to be able to signal rclone-mount to update the dir cache
I've put it on the list for 1.37

I have another suggestion:
Why doesn't activate the function to refresh the cache every time rclone makes a change on the remote?
For example, these rclone functions could trigger a function to refresh the cache because they are all "write" actions (at least when "writing" to the remote):
rclone copy - Copy files from source to dest, skipping already copied
rclone move - Move files from source to dest.
rclone delete - Remove the contents of path.
rclone purge - Remove the path and all of its contents.
rclone mkdir - Make the path if it doesn’t already exist.
rclone rmdir - Remove the path.
rclone rmdirs - Remove any empty directoryies under the path.
rclone cleanup - Clean up the remote if possible
rclone dedupe - Interactively find duplicate files delete/rename them.
rclone copyto - Copy files from source to dest, skipping already copied
rclone moveto - Move file or directory from source to dest.
@chmercesmoreira nice idea, but not straight forward to implement as it is two different instance of rclone running so one would have to find the other which is non-trivial...

I took a stab at implementing a more sophisticated version of this – where you can invalidate specific paths instead of the "all or nothing" approach suggested here. That would be a perquisite to hook into the GDrive changes API, for instance.

I am not sure how to solve this in a memory leak free way, though. [bazil/fuse/fs](https://github.com/bazil/fuse/blob/master/fs/serve.go) holds the reference to all nodes (and thus rclone's `Dir`s) in a private map `nodeRefs`. Since I cannot access that map, I cannot simply iterate over its keys until I find a node with a matching path and discard that `Dir`'s `items`.

Idea 1: Create a lookup `map[string]*Dir`. That might keep `Dir`s around that get removed from the `nodeRefs`, e.g. by `dropNode`. Seems like a very fragile approach to catch all cases to ensure it also gets dropped from rclone's lookup.

Idea 2: Collect list of invalidated directories and remove it again when the matching directory is re-read. Of course, old entries from that list can be discarded once they are older than `dirCacheTime`. Still, if the idea is to set the dir caching time to essentially ∞, invalidation requests for non-existing dirs would hang around forever.

Idea 3: Idea 2, but immediately re-read the directory. This would not be flushing, but rather refreshing, but at least it should not leak. 

Both 2+3 suffer from not working recursively, I think. E.g. if I have `dir1/dir2/file` and invalidate `dir1`, only `dir1` contents will be re-read. `dir2` will not be affected. If that is desired/needed, then it would have to recurse once it is invalidated. Combined with `Dir.rename`, which sets `d.items = nil`, this seems to have a high potential for hard to debug race conditions.

Idea 4: fork the fuse library and make `nodeRefs` accessible, so that we can iterate. 

None of the ideas sound really appealing to me, though. If someone has some insight (or spies a mistake in my reasoning), I'd be happy to hear it.
@breunigs it seems to me the best approach might be to send a PR to bazil/fuse/fs with the extra functionality rclone needs.  Perhaps a flush this path method and return nodes flushed?

I suspect that a subdir's inode does not change when a parent directory is renamed. As such, basil/fuse keeps the reference to rclone's `Dir` around, which of course contains the full `path` – this is why it reads `a/b/c` at the end, instead of the expected `a/bb/c`. It is correct on the remote end.

I will probably solve this alongside #803, but here is in case I don't manage.

issue.title: allow to manually flush the mount cache (fixes #803)

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
some comments on this PR:
* I will rebase/squash when this is ready. I expect your review will yield some more changes :)
* fixes #803, and allows fine grained eviction if needed
* I did not need to modify bazil/fuse after all: It already offers a callback through `NodeForgetter` when it discards something on its side. Together with the already implemented rename/remove, this should cover all cases.
* the extra code in `func (d *Dir) rename(…)` is to fix #1375. I experience it when I test manually with GDrive mounted, but I didn't manage to write a failing test case. I'll have to see in #1375 if this is just a bug in GDrive, just not present in the local backend used in test cases or maybe a timing related issue…
* I wonder if SIGHUP is a good signal choice. I would prefer something like SIGUSR1, but if I read [correctly this is not available on Windows](https://github.com/golang/sys/blob/ff24cb3cd86e67842e0d078a5e0cb92d9ffcf8b4/windows/ztypes_windows.go#L51-L84). What about SIGALRM? If not, rclone should probably ignore SIGHUP in other modes, because users might otherwise accidentally kill a running sync if they pass the wrong PID.

## Directory Cache ###
 +
 +Using the ` + "`--dir-cache-time`" + ` flag, you can set how long a
 +directory should be considered up to date and not refreshed from the
 +backend. Changes made locally in the mount may appear immediately or
 +invalidate the cache. However, changes done on the remote will only
 +be picked up once the cache expires.
 +
 +Alternatively, you can send a ` + "`SIGHUP`" + ` signal to rclone for
 +it to flush all directory caches, regardless of how old they are.
 +Assuming only one rlcone instance is running, you can reset the cache
 +like this:
 +
 +    kill -SIGHUP $(pidof rclone)
 +
